revision.comment: /* Celebrity impersonations */Who is not a celebrity
revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{incomplete|date=February 2017}} {{update|date=February 2017}} {{BLP primary sources|article|date=March 2008}} }} {{Infobox person |name = Joe Piscopo |image = JoePiscopoByPhilKonstantin.JPG |caption = Piscopo in 2009 |birth_name = Joseph Charles John Piscopo |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1951|6|17}} |birth_place = [[Passaic, New Jersey]], U.S. |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] {{small|(before 2008)}}
[[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] {{small|(2008–present)}} |spouse = {{marriage|Nancy Jones|1973|1988}}
{{marriage|Kimberly Driscoll|1997|2006}} |children = 4 |education = [[Jones College (Jacksonville)|Jones College]] {{small|([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])}} |occupation = Actor, comedian |years_active = 1975–present }} '''Joseph Charles John Piscopo''' (pronounced ''PIS-co-po''; born June 17, 1951) is an American comedian, actor, musician, writer, and a nationally syndicated radio talk show host. He is best known for his work on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' in the early 1980s where he played a variety of recurring characters. ==Early life== Born in [[Passaic, New Jersey]], Piscopo grew up in [[North Caldwell, New Jersey|North Caldwell]]Staff. [https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/courierpostonline/access/1847997561.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Mar+22%2C+1999&author=&pub=Courier+Post&desc=The+HBO+series%2C+`The+Sopranos%2C'+features+Steve+Van+Zandt+(from+left)%2C+Tony+Sirico+and+James+Gandolfini.&pqatl=google "The HBO series, `The Sopranos,' features Steve Van Zandt (from left), Tony Sirico and James Gandolfini."], ''[[Courier-Post]]'', March 22, 1999. Accessed December 23, 2014. "Actor-comedian Joe Piscopo grew up in the neighborhood where the show is set, North Caldwell, Essex County." and attended [[West Essex High School]] and was a member of the drama club "the Masquers".Strauss, Robert. [https://www.nytimes.com/2005/08/07/nyregion/nyregionspecial2/07njPERSON.html "So Jersey, He Deserves His Own Rest Area"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', August 7, 2005. Accessed March 14, 2011. "Mr. Piscopo's father, also named Joe, was a lawyer and the family mostly lived in Essex County, the younger Joe graduating from West Essex High School in North Caldwell. With his ''Saturday Night Live'' fame, he moved to one of the richest corners of New Jersey, Alpine, persuading Mr. Murphy to join him there in that wealthy enclave by the Palisades." He developed a reputation for never playing a part the way it was written. After graduating from high school in 1969, Piscopo attended [[Jones College (Jacksonville)|Jones College]] in [[Jacksonville, Florida]], where he received a degree in broadcast management.{{cite book|author1=Maxine N. Lurie|author2=Marc Mappen|title=The Encyclopedia of New Jersey|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_r9Ni6_u0JEC&pg=PA640|accessdate=13 December 2012|date=1 April 2004|publisher=Rutgers University Press|isbn=978-0-8135-3325-4|pages=640–}} ==''Saturday Night Live''== In the summer of 1980, Piscopo was hired as a contract player for ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''. The show had gone through major upheaval when all the writers, major producers, and cast members left that spring. The all-new cast bombed with critics and fans, with the exception of Piscopo and [[Eddie Murphy]]; thus they were the only two cast members to be kept when [[Dick Ebersol]] took over the show the following spring. With the success of ''SNL'', Piscopo moved to the wealthy borough of [[Alpine, New Jersey]]. Piscopo was best known for his impressions of celebrities such as [[Frank Sinatra]], although he allegedly feared for his life due to [[Personal life of Frank Sinatra#Alleged organized-crime links|Sinatra's alleged Mafia ties]]. Piscopo rewrote the lyrics for a Sinatra sketch with the help of Sinatra lyricist [[Sammy Cahn]], and recalled that "by the grace of God, the old man loved it."{{cite episode | title=Saturday Night Live Backstage | network=NBC | airdate=2011-02-20}} ==Post–''Saturday Night Live'' career== Piscopo left Saturday Night Live at the end of the 1983–1984 season. In 1984, he starred in a special for [[HBO]] and released a book for [[Pocket Books]] called ''The Piscopo Tapes''. An album, ''New Jersey'', for Columbia Records followed in 1985{{cite web |url=https://www.discogs.com/Joe-Piscopo-New-Jersey/release/2973674 |title=Joe Piscopo - New Jersey |publisher=[[Discogs]]}} and an [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] special called ''The Joe Piscopo New Jersey Special'' in May 1986.{{cite web |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1986-05-13/features/8602030441_1_allen-funt-danny-devito-first-name-basis |title=Piscopo Occasionally Ready for Prime Time|publisher=}} In 1987, Piscopo was name-checked in [[Tom Petty]] and the Heartbreakers' #1 rock single "[[Jammin' Me]]". Since January 2014 he has hosted ''Piscopo in the Morning'' with Al Gattullo, Frank Morano, and Debbie DuHaime from 6:00 to 10:00 a.m., Monday through Friday on [[WNYM|AM 970 The Answer (WNYM)]] in New York City.http://feeds.soundcloud.com/users/soundcloud:users:54981657/sounds.rss By February 2017, Piscopo, a supporter of U.S. President [[Donald Trump]], was considering running as an independent for [[Governor of New Jersey]] in the [[New Jersey gubernatorial election, 2017|2017 gubernatorial election]]. However, in April he decided not to do so.{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/20/nyregion/joe-piscopo-new-jersey-governor.html |title=Joe Piscopo Considers Running for Governor of New Jersey. No Joke.|last=Corasaniti|first=Nick|date=2017-02-20|newspaper=The New York Times|access-date=2017-02-21|issn=0362-4331}}[http://miami.cbslocal.com/2017/05/03/snl-trump-joe-piscopo-wont-run-new-jersey-governor/ "Joe Piscopo won't run for New Jersey governor"], [[CBS Miami]] (AP), May 3, 2017. Retrieved 3 May 2017. ==Personal life== Piscopo married former ''[[Wheel of Fortune (U.S. game show)|Wheel of Fortune]]'' producer Nancy Jones in 1973. They had one child and divorced in 1988. He married Kimberly Driscoll in 1997. They had three children and divorced in 2006.{{cite news|last1=Terruso|first1=Julia|title=Judge orders Joe Piscopo to pay $10K in child support|url=http://www.nj.com/news/index.ssf/2012/11/judge_orders_joe_piscopo_to_pa.html|work=The Star-Ledger|date=November 30, 2012}} Piscopo is a resident of [[Lebanon Township, New Jersey]].Staff. [http://www.theleftcoaster.com/archives/003870.php "On the Comeback Trail: John Kerry and...Joe Piscopo?"], ''The left coaster'', March 9, 2005. Accessed June 11, 2009.Jennings, Rob. [http://www.nj.com/sussex-county/index.ssf/2017/04/joe_piscopo_insists_hes_still_thinking_of_running.html "Joe Piscopo insists he's still thinking of running for N.J. governor"], NJ Advance Media for [[NJ.com]], April 7, 2017. Accessed September 2, 2017. "Piscopo, who lives in Lebanon Township, suggested he would tap into a similar base of support if he runs." Piscopo is a fan of the Brooklyn Nets. ==Filmography== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! Title ! Role |- | 1976 | ''[[King Kong (1976 film)|King Kong]]'' | Bit Part (uncredited) |- | 1977 | ''[[American Tickler]]'' | Announcer |- | rowspan="3"|1984 | ''[[Johnny Dangerously]]'' | Danny Vermin |- | ''[[The House of God]]'' | Dr. Fishberg |- | ''The Joe Piscopo Special'' (TV Special) | Himself |- |rowspan="4"|1986 | ''Julian Lennon: Stick Around'' (Video short) | Rival |- | ''[[New Jersey Vice]]'' (Short Movie) | |- | ''[[The Joe Piscopo New Jersey Special]]'' | Himself |- | ''[[Wise Guys (1986 film)|Wise Guys]]'' | Moe Dickstein |- | 1988 | ''[[Dead Heat (1988 film)|Dead Heat]]'' | Doug Bigelow |- | 1992 | ''[[Sidekicks (1992 film)|Sidekicks]]'' | Kelly Stone |- | 1994 | ''Huck and the King of Hearts'' | Max |- |rowspan="3"|1995 | ''Open Season'' | Hamlet |- | ''[[Two Bits & Pepper]]'' | Zike / Pepper |- | ''Captain Nuke and the Bomber Boys'' | Mr. Wareman |- | 2000 | ''Baby Bedlam'' | Jack |- | 2001 | ''[[Bartleby (2001 film)|Bartleby]]'' | Rocky |- | rowspan="2"|2006 | ''[[Last Request (film)|Last Request]]'' | Angelo |- | ''[[Dead Lenny]]'' | Louis Long |- | 2012 | ''[[Spring Break '83]]'' | Max's Father |- | 2013 | ''[[How Sweet It Is (2013 film)|How Sweet It Is]]'' | Jack Cosmo |} ==Celebrity impersonations== {| class="wikitable" |- | * [[Allen Funt]] * [[Andy Rooney]] * [[Barbra Streisand]] * [[Bruce Lee]] * [[Bruce Springsteen]] * [[Carl XVI Gustaf]] * [[Curly Howard]] * [[Dan Rather]] * [[David Hartman (TV personality)|David Hartman]] * [[David Letterman]] * [[Dean Martin]] * [[Don Pardo]] * [[Donnie Wahlberg]] * [[Doug Llewelyn]] | * [[Ed McMahon]] * [[Ed Sullivan]] * [[Eddie Constantine]] * [[Frank Sinatra]] * [[Geraldo Rivera]] * [[Hattie McDaniel]] * [[Howard Stern]] * [[James G. Watt]] * [[Jerry Lewis]] * [[Jerry Sandusky]] * [[Jesse Jackson]] * [[Jim Fowler]] * [[Jimmy Carter]] * [[Joan Rivers]] * [[John B. Anderson|John Anderson]] | * [[John F. Kennedy]] * [[John Kenneth Galbraith]] * [[John McEnroe]] * [[John Newcombe]] * [[Karl Malden]] * [[Lee Iacocca]] * [[Leonard Nimoy]] * [[Lorne Greene]] * [[Marvin Hamlisch]] * [[Pat Cooper]] * [[Paul Harvey]] * [[Peter Marshall (game show host)|Peter Marshall]] * [[Peter Yarrow]] | * [[Phil Donahue]] * [[Pope John Paul II]] * [[Rex Reed]] * [[Richard Nixon]] * [[Robert De Niro]] * [[Robin Leach]] * [[Ronald Reagan]] * [[Steve Lawrence]] * [[Sylvester Stallone]] * [[Ted Koppel]] * [[Tom Carvel]] * [[Tom Snyder]] * [[Winston Churchill]] |} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb name|685472}} * {{Official website|http://www.joepiscopo.com}} {{NYC Morning Drive}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Piscopo, Joe}} [[Category:1951 births]] [[Category:American impressionists (entertainers)]] [[Category:American male film actors]] [[Category:American male musical theatre actors]] [[Category:American male television actors]] [[Category:American male voice actors]] [[Category:American sketch comedians]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:New Jersey Republicans]] [[Category:People from Alpine, New Jersey]] [[Category:People from Lebanon Township, New Jersey]] [[Category:People from North Caldwell, New Jersey]] [[Category:People from Passaic, New Jersey]] [[Category:People from Tewksbury Township, New Jersey]] [[Category:20th-century American comedians]] [[Category:21st-century American comedians]]
